channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Putin Confirms He Is Running for President
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at a volunteer forum in Moscow on Wednesday.
item.description: In a choreographed announcement in a factory setting, he said he would stand for a fourth term as president in March. He is expected to win handily.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.category: Communist Party of the Russian Federation

item.title: Halifax Journal: Century After Halifax’s Great Explosion, City Marks Anniversary
item.media:description: Halifax’s harbor after the explosion in December 1917. The blast leveled much of the north end of the city and killed about 2,000 people.
item.description: The 1917 blast after a collision between a French munitions ship and a Norwegian vessel killed about 2,000 people and leveled part of the Canadian city.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: China Scolds Australia Over Its Fears of Foreign Influence
item.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia with China’s president, Xi Jinping, in the Chinese city of Hangzhou last year. Mr. Turnbull proposed laws this week aimed at curbing foreign influence in Australian politics.
item.description: The Chinese Embassy accused Australian officials of damaging “mutual trust,” a day after laws were proposed to curb interference by other countries in Australian politics.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Israeli-Palestinian Reflexes Take Over in U.S. Embassy Dispute
item.media:description: A viewpoint overlooking the Old City of Jerusalem on Wednesday. News that President Trump would formally recognize the city as Israel’s capital seemed to be taking a bit of time to sink in.
item.description: An Israeli minister said the move to Jerusalem would be “destiny,” while the leader of Hamas called it “an unaccountable gamble.”
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Montreal Journal: Quebec Tries to Say Au Revoir to ‘Hi,’ and Hello to ‘Bonjour’
item.media:description: Wilensky’s Light Lunch in Montreal. Quebec’s legislators last week unanimously passed a resolution calling for shopkeepers to stop saying “Bonjour hi” when they greet customers and to say “Bonjour” instead.
item.media:credit: Robert Wright for The New York Times
item.description: Quebec’s legislature has passed a motion calling for merchants to greet customers with “Bonjour” rather than the unofficial “Bonjour Hi.”
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: Office Quebecois de la Langue Francaise

item.title: The Conflict in Jerusalem Is Distinctly Modern. Here’s the History.
item.media:description: An aerial view of Jerusalem's Old City.
item.description: The city has long been contested by Jews, Christians and Muslims, as well as by external powers, and its future remains far from clear.
item.dc:creator: MONA BOSHNAQ, SEWELL CHAN, IRIT PAZNER GARSHOWITZ and GAIA TRIPOLI

item.title: A Long-Dead Cambodian King Is Back — and He Looks Familiar
item.media:description: A statue of the 16th-century ruler Sdech Kan in Prey Veng, Cambodia. At least seven statues of the once-obscure king have gone up in recent years, all with faces resembling Prime Minister Hun Sen’s.
item.media:credit: Quinn Ryan Mattingly for The New York Times
item.description: Some think Prime Minister Hun Sen considers himself the reincarnation of a 16th-century ruler. Recently built statues certainly suggest a resemblance.
item.dc:creator: JULIA WALLACE

item.title: Son of Slain Yemen Leader Is Said to Vow Revenge
item.media:description: The presidential palace in Sana, Yemen, on Tuesday, after warplanes from a Saudi-led coalition were said to have struck it and other targets.
item.description: The warning by Ahmed Ali Saleh, an American-trained former military commander, could signal his emergence as a focus of opposition to Houthi rebels.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and ALAN COWELL

item.title: In Era of Trump, Germany Seeks a Stronger Role Abroad
item.media:description: The acting foreign minister of Germany, Sigmar Gabriel, speaking in Berlin on Tuesday. European countries, he said, “must be able to define our own position and, if necessary, draw red lines.”
item.description: The acting foreign minister, Sigmar Gabriel, calls for a bolder foreign policy role for Berlin, as Germans say they worry more about the U.S. than North Korea or Iran.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Full Video and Transcript: Trump’s Speech Recognizing Jerusalem as the Capital of Israel
item.description: President Trump officially recognized Jerusalem as the capital of Israel on Wednesday, reversing decades of American foreign policy.

item.title: Full Video: President Trump Speaks on Jerusalem
item.description: President Trump has recognized Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. The decision bucks nearly seven decades of American foreign policy.

item.title: The World’s Biggest Starbucks Opens in Shanghai. Here’s What It Looks Like.
item.media:description: The opening ceremony of the new Starbucks Reserve Roastery in Shanghai on Wednesday.
item.description: The company’s new store in China is aimed squarely at a country of tea drinkers that has emerged as a major core of its business.
item.dc:creator: AILIN TANG

item.title: Tech We’re Using: What Tech Tools Frequent Travelers Should Always Pack
item.media:description: Lucas Peterson, who writes the Frugal Traveler column, at a hotel in Miami this week. He said he didn’t see much difference between the various online booking agencies.
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.description: You should always have a portable battery to charge your phone. But other must-haves are not as obvious, says Lucas Peterson, The Times’s Frugal Traveler.
item.dc:creator: LUCAS PETERSON

item.title: Russia Won’t Keep Athletes Home, Putin Says After Olympics Ban
item.media:description: The Russian Olympic Committee headquarters in Moscow. The Russian team has been barred from the 2018 Winter Games in South Korea.
item.description: In a surprisingly conciliatory move, the Russian president said he would not stop individuals competing at the 2018 Winter Games on their own account.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Chinese Newspaper Publishes Precautions for Nuclear Conflict
item.media:description: The river marking the border between North Korea, background, and China’s Jilin province.
item.description: The main official newspaper for a province abutting North Korea listed ways to limit radiation exposure, even including cartoons.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: What World Leaders Think of Jerusalem as Israel’s Capital
item.description: Global and regional leaders warned of the dangers of declaring Jerusalem as Israel’s capital. President Trump announced the change on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Recognizes Jerusalem as Israel’s Capital
item.description: Ignoring warnings from diplomats around the world, President Trump reverses decades of American policy toward the divided city.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Pope Francis Voices ‘Deep Concern’ Over Trump Plan on Jerusalem
item.media:description: Protesters burned the flags of Israel and the United States in Gaza City on Wednesday.
item.description: “I cannot remain silent” about a situation in the Holy Land, he said, which risks adding “new elements of tension.”
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Malta Charges 3 Veteran Criminals in Journalist’s Murder
item.media:description: A suspect being escorted out of the Law Courts in Valletta, Malta, on Wednsday, after being charged with the murder of the journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia.
item.description: While welcomed, the arrests have done little to dispel doubts that whoever ordered the killing of Daphne Caruana Galizia will see justice.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Plot to Kill U.K. Prime Minister Foiled, Court Hears
item.media:description: Police officers outside 10 Downing Street in London, the official residence of the British prime minister, on Wednesday.
item.description: Prosecutors described a plan to bomb Theresa May’s offices and residence on Downing Street and then to stab her to death.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: State of the Art: The Hidden Player Spurring a Wave of Cheap Consumer Devices: Amazon
item.description: Numerous electronics brands have sprung up offering inexpensive gadgets. Here’s how Amazon enables them, and how other brands may copy that success.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: Zarrab’s Take From Iran Sanctions Plot? ‘Maybe $150 Million,’ He Says
item.media:description: Reza Zarrab in Istanbul in 2013.
item.description: Reza Zarrab, under cross-examination by the defense, admitted that he had made a fortune helping Turkey evade U.S.-imposed sanctions on Iran.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Olympics, Jerusalem, John Conyers: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Banned From Winter Olympics, Russia Faces Greatest Sports Crisis Since Soviet Era
item.media:description: The opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, in 2014.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: The decision carries the whiff of history, although back then the conflicts were rooted in political ideology rather than performance-enhancing drugs.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Scenes of Devastation From California’s Latest Wildfire
item.media:description: A firefighter trying to contain a wildfire in Ventura, Calif. More than 1,000 firefighters are battling the flames.
item.description: More than 150 buildings have been destroyed and thousands of homes have been evacuated in Southern California. The fire shows no signs of letting up.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER MEDINA

item.title: Myanmar’s Rohingya Actions May Be Genocide, U.N. Official Says
item.media:description: Rohingya refugees arriving in Bangladesh in September.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, detailed “acts of appalling barbarity” by the Myanmar military.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Why Jerusalem Is So Contested
item.description: President Trump declared recognition of Jerusalem as Israel’s capital. Here’s why that’s so fraught.

item.title: It’s Official: Lebanese Prime Minister Not Resigning After All
item.media:description: Prime Minister Saad Hariri of Lebanon, center, rescinded his resignation at a cabinet meeting at the presidential palace on Tuesday.
item.description: What happens in Saudi Arabia stays in Saudi Arabia, including the short-lived surprise resignation of Prime Minister Saad Hariri of Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Inside China’s Big Tech Conference, New Ways to Track Citizens
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China shown on a screen during the fourth World Internet Conference in Wuzhen.
item.description: The technologies for tracking citizens, and their wide acceptance in China, were on display at the World Internet Conference.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Austria Allows Gay Marriage in Court Ruling
item.media:description: The Regenbogenparade, or Rainbow Parade, in Vienna in June.
item.description: It became the 16th European country to grant marriage equality.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: U.S. to Recognize Jerusalem as Israel’s Capital, Trump Says, Alarming Middle East Leaders
item.description: Igniting fears of violence in the region, President Trump’s decision could derail any peace initiative, Arab and European leaders warn.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Ex-Leader of Georgia Confronts Ukraine Agents in Rooftop Standoff
item.media:description: Ukrainian security officers arresting Mikheil Saakashvili, the former president of Georgia, in Kiev on Tuesday.
item.description: Mikheil Saakashvili, an increasingly bitter opponent of the Ukrainian president, led protests after threatening to jump during an aborted arrest.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Toblerone vs. Poundland: A Food Fight With Peaks and Troughs
item.media:description: Seeing double? A Toblerone bar, top, and Twin Peaks, a rival produced by the British discount chain Poundland.
item.description: After the Swiss company reconfigured its iconic Matterhorn-shaped chocolate bar, the British discount chain released a rival, Twin Peaks. (Lawyers were called.)
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Rex Tillerson, Visiting Europe, Gets Cold Shoulder
item.media:description: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson with Federica Mogherini, the European Union foreign policy chief, in Brussels on Tuesday. “A way must be found through negotiations to resolve the status of Jerusalem as a future capital of both states,” she said.
item.description: The chilly reception given to the secretary of state in Brussels reflected concerns about President Trump’s positions on Jerusalem and Iran.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Russia Designates U.S.-Backed Broadcasters as ‘Foreign Agents’
item.media:description: The Prague newsroom of Current Time, a Russian-language network run by Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty.
item.description: The Kremlin acted against Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty and Voice of America after Washington took similar steps against the Russian news channel RT and news agency Sputnik.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: King Michael of Romania, Who Ousted a Hitler Puppet, Dies at 96
item.media:description: King Michael acknowledging applause after speaking in Romania’s Parliament in 2011. Beside him was his eldest daughter, Princess Margareta, and her husband, Prince Radu Duda, left.
item.description: First becoming king at age 5, Michael, at just 22, may have shortened World War II by arresting his country’s fascist dictator. He later went into exile.
item.dc:creator: DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: China Will Lead an Electric Car Future, Ford’s Chairman Says
item.media:description: Fords at an auto show in Guangzhou, China, last month. Ford Motor said Tuesday that it planned to introduce 15 models in China by 2025 that run at least in part on batteries.
item.description: Ford Motor said Tuesday that it planned to offer 15 new models in China by 2025 that run at least in part on batteries.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Warrant for Carles Puigdemont, Catalan Separatist, Is Withdrawn
item.media:description: The ousted Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont, third from left, at an event in Brussels with mayors and former councillors from the region this month.
item.description: Mr. Puigdemont and four former members of his cabinet had fled to Belgium, saying they could not receive a fair trial at home.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Jet Pilots Say They Saw North Korean Missile in Flight
item.media:description: North Korea released this photo, which it said showed the launch of its Hwasong-15 missile on Wednesday. Crews from three commercial jets reported seeing the missile over the Sea of Japan.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: Crews from three commercial flights reported seeing what appeared to be the missile the North launched last week. Experts said the risk to planes was low but real.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Google Missed Out on China. Can It Flourish in India?
item.media:description: Cellphone users in Jodhpur, India, where Google sent a researcher this week to get feedback about apps. Google is changing core products in India to use less data and work better on low-end smartphones.
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.description: As major companies chase India’s new internet users, Google is changing core products to work better on low-end smartphones and use less data.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL

item.title: Amazon’s Australian Debut Brings Excitement, Dread and Defiance
item.media:description: Amazon’s debut in the Australian marketplace featured only a few hundred sellers — or third-party vendors.
item.description: The retail giant started off with a modest product offering, seeking to steal a piece of Australia’s retail sector.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: Honduran Vote Recount Urged as Tally Shows President Is Ahead
item.description: Honduran election officials said President Juan Orlando Hernández had won a narrow margin of votes, but international monitors asked for recounts.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Australia Diary: Australia Diary: Kindness, Poetry and Song
item.media:description: The huge and terrifying huntsman spider.
item.description: The first installment of a new weekly feature, collecting reader tales from Australia.
item.dc:creator: DIANA OLIVA CAVE

item.title: Reza Zarrab, Taped in Jail, Said Lying Was Ticket to Freedom
item.media:description: “Reza says in such a country, in order to get out or get a reduced sentence, you need to admit to crimes you haven’t committed.” Reza Zarrab in 2013.
item.description: “To get out or get a reduced sentence, you need to admit to crimes you haven’t committed,” the prosecution witness in an Iran sanctions case said.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Brexit Talks Hit Hurdle as D.U.P. Balks at Irish Border Plan
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain and the European Commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker, before a meeting in Brussels on Monday.
item.description: A Northern Irish party scuppered a deal Prime Minister Theresa May had reached with the E.U., denying her a much-needed breakthrough in the stalled talks.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Utah, Roy Moore, Travel Ban: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Ali Abdullah Saleh, Strongman Who Helped Unite Yemen, and Divide It, Dies at 75
item.media:description: Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen at the presidential palace in Sana in 2008.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: A former president who left a legacy of corruption, he re-emerged to play a major role in his country’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
